nodes.text: An input-aware selective instruction duplication (SID) framework that adapts protection to runtime inputs can significantly reduce silent data corruption (SDC) coverage loss compared to existing input-agnostic SID methods while remaining lightweight at runtime
Existing SID methods derive instruction vulnerability from fault injection under a default reference input and assume vulnerability profiles are input-invariant
Input variations change control flow and execution frequencies, causing shifts in SDC propagation and resulting in substantial SDC coverage loss when using static SID plans

Protego: a two-phase approach â€” one-time offline SDC vulnerability-guided input exploration and grouping, plus a lightweight online input-to-group mapping to select precomputed SID-protected executables

Protego offline phase performs an optimization-guided search generating 500 unique inputs via mutation and crossover, evaluates each with fault injection to obtain instruction-level SDC profiles, and prioritizes inputs that deviate most from existing profiles

Protego online phase extracts five lightweight features from input arguments, uses a trained MLP to estimate overall SDC vulnerability, maps the input to a precomputed input group, and returns the representative SID-protected executable for that group

Fault injection methodology used: inject faults at LLVM IR level; 1000 random faults to measure overall application SDC probability per input and 100 random faults per instruction to estimate instruction-level SDC probability; this yields 95% confidence error bars consistent with prior work

Because static SID plans are optimized for a single reference input, when applied to different inputs they can overprotect inactive regions and underprotect newly active vulnerable regions, lowering SDC coverage

Empirical observation: across 30 inputs for each of 10 HPC applications, SDC coverage produced by reference-input SID often falls substantially below expected coverage, confirming non-generalizability

Input grouping: cluster the 500 explored inputs into a small number of groups by allowing at most 10% maximum SDC coverage loss within a group; select the median-SDC-rate input as representative and generate its SID-protected executable

Feature selection and model: derive candidate transforms from input arguments, pick top-5 features by mutual information, train an MLP (five hidden layers 512-256-128-64-32, ReLU, Adam, batch size 8, 10000 iterations) to predict overall SDC rate
Offline cost: average input search time ~3500 minutes and representative SID evaluation time ~880 minutes across evaluated applications; model training time is negligible (~6 seconds)

MLP prediction accuracy evidence: low mean absolute error between predicted and ground-truth overall SDC rates across evaluated applications (per-application MAE values reported), enabling reliable input-group selection

Runtime efficiency evidence: Protego selects and returns an appropriate SID-protected executable in about 0.05 seconds on average per input, achieving ~100x speedup over full duplication runtime deployment

Effectiveness results: across 10 HPC applications and 100 unseen online inputs, Protego reduces mean SDC coverage loss compared to baseline static SID (baseline average losses at 10%,30%,50%,70% were 23.81%,18.76%,16.36%,13.14%; Protego reduced these to 15.18%,12.71%,11.62%,8.43%)

Case study on high SDC-prone inputs: for inputs with high intrinsic SDC vulnerability, existing SID methods show large coverage loss (average 22.89%) while Protego limits coverage loss (average 6.41%), demonstrating particular advantage under high-risk inputs

Limitation and future opportunity: the one-time offline FI-guided search and SID evaluations are costly; later-stage inputs often repeat profiles suggesting potential to reduce offline cost by reusing profiles and conditionally skipping FI
